p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA ANNUAL REPORT OF THE STATE TAX COMMISSIONER AND THE State Board of Equalization and Assessment FOR THE YEAR 1926

MEMBERS OF THE BOARD ADAM McMULLEN Governor CHARLES W. POOL. Secretary of State GEORGE W. MARSH -State Auditor C. D. ROBINSON State Treasurer T. E. WILLIAMS State Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the constitu - tion of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commissioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Com - missioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY Custer SERVED W. H. OSBORNE WM. H. SMITH T. E. WILLIAMS April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 April 18, 1923 to Jan. 12, 1925 Jan. 12, 1925, to Seward Hamilton

> LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL November 30th, 1926 Hon. Adam McMullen, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Sir: Herewith is transmitted the annual report of this department for the year 1926. In doing so I want to express the appreciation of the de - partment for the co-operation of yourself and the other members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. I also want to express my thanks to the County Assessors and County Clerks of the state for their help, and to the other county officers upon whom it has been neces - sary to make frequent calls for co-operation. Your very truly, T. E. WILLIAMS, State Tax Commissioner.

STATE OF NEBRASKA 101 STATEMENT NO. 5 State Levy for the Year 1926 The following resolution fixing the State Levy for 1926 was unanimouly adopted by the State Board of Equalization and Assess- ment on August 2, 1926. WHEREAS: From the Auditor's Report it appears that there was appropriated to be paid out of the General Fund the sum of $14,320,086.84 for the biennium, one-half of which should be met for the current year which is $7,160,043.42. To meet which it is estimated there will be available miscellaneous collections for the General Fund not otherwise appro- priated $ 960,000.00 General Fund balance in State Treasury on July 1, 1926 638,423.60 General Fund Collections in hands of County Treasurers, July 1, 1926, but not remitted 486,000.00 2,084,423.60 Leaving to be raised from the 1926 gen- eral fund levy 5,075,619.82 The assessed valuation of the tangible property of the state being 3,177,853,200 And the assessed valuation of the in- tangible property being 144,877,174 which is equivalent to 35,598,064 tangible property, a levy of 1.58 mills will raise 5,077,252.99 The Capitol fund levy as fixed by law is .22 of one mill and on the assessed valuation of the state will raise 706,959.27 THEREFORE, Be it resolved that the levies for 1926 be made as follows: General Fund 1.58 mills $5,077,252.99 Capitol Fund .22 mills 706,959.27 Total, 1926 Taxes 1.80 mills 5,784,212.26

112 REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 10 1926 INTANGIBLES In 1926, county assessors of Nebraska assessed intangibles, Class A, in the sum of $69,046,116; Class B, $75,536,104. Class A intangibles are taxed at 2% mills on the dollar and Class B intangibles are taxed at 5 mills on the dollar, as provided by the 1925 Legislature. These classes are itemized as follows, with the total valuation in the state of each item: Class A (NOTE— The tax rate on money is 2% mills on the dollar). Valuation Money, United States legal tender notes and otheT securities of the United States payable on demand, savings ac - counts, bank deposits, bills of exchange, checks & drafts $69,046,116 200% PENALTY FOR REFUSAL TO LIST. TOTAL $69,046,116 Class B (NOTE — The tax rate on this kind of property is 5 mills on the dollar). Valuation 1. Shares of stock in corporations, the Capital Stock of which is not assessed or taxed in this state $12,992,687 2. Stock or shares of domestic building and loan associa - tions 2,641,490 3. Notes (other than notes secured by mortgages on real estate situated in this state), bills of exchange, due bills, cream checks and similar evidence of indebtedness 15,676,907 4. Judgments, choses in action and liens of any kind (other than notes secured by mortgage on real estate situated in this state) 639,362 5. Securities, debentures and bonds (other than those of the United States or of this state or governmental subdi - vision of this state) 3,679,919 6. Book accounts and other similar open accounts 27,789,932 7. Contracts for cash or labor and all other demands for labor or other valuable thing, whether due or to be - come due 1,045,585 8. Annuities, royalties and all sums of money receivable at stated periods 219,428 9. Real Estate Mortgages upon lands situated outside of this state and amount secured thereby 2,214,314 10. Chattel Mortgages upon personal property in this state or elsewhere, and the amount secured thereby 3,250,427 11. All claims and demands for money or other valuable thing not above enumerated 5,384,238 12. 200% PENALTY ADDED FOR REFUSAL TO LIST... 1,815 5,384,238 TOTAL VALUATION $75,536,104 The law provides that the tax on intangible property figured on the valuations as above stated shall be distributed by the county clerk to the various governmental subdivisions of his county in the ratio that the levy of each subdivision bears to the total levy on the property in that subdivision.
